Question: Six sets of twins ( a boy and a girl in every case) made several errors in their history and geography examinations; and it was noted that every girl made precisely the same number of errors as her brother in the two subjects. Name each pair of siblings and their surname and work out how many mistakes each made in their history and geography examination papers.
1. The boy (not Luke) whose sister is Louella made more history errors than Sammy.
2. George did better in history than the boy surnamed O'Connell, who made either one more or one less geography error than the twins surnamed Dean.
3. Anne made either one more or one less geography error than Louella.
4. The twins who made 11 geography errors didn't make exactly 11 history errors.
5. David and his sister made either one more or one less mistake in the history exam than the twins who made 14 geography errors.
6. Edward and his sister did worse at history than the pair who made 15 geography errors. Edward made one more error in the geography exam than Luke.
7. The McCall twins didn't make one less history mistake than the Vole twins.
8. Susan (who made seven history errors) made one less geography error than the girl who made one less history error than Anne.
9. The twins surnamed Waters made one more history mistake than the twins surnamed Seal, who made more geography errors than the McCall twins.
10. Gail made one more geography error than the girl who made one more history error than Louella.
11. Martin made either one more or one less geography error than his best friend and his sister, who made more history mistakes than Diane.
12. Wendy and her brother (who didn't make eight history mistakes) didn't make as many errors in geography as George and his sister.
Brothers are David, Edward, George, Luke, Martin & Sammy.
Sisters are Anne, Diane, Gail, Louella, Susan & Wendy.
Surnames are Dean, McCall, O'Connell, Seal, Vole & Waters.
Geography errors are 10, 11, 12, 14, 15 & 16.
History errors are 6, 7, 8, 10, 11 & 12.
 Solution: Susan made seven history errors (clue 8) and no one made nine, so Anne made either 11 or 12. Louella didn't make six history errors (1), so (10) must have made either 10 or 11. If Louella made 11 and Anne made 12, then Susan made one less geography error than Louella (8) and Gail made one more than Anne (10). But then, since no one made 13 geography errors, clue 3 doesn't work. So Louella made 10 history errors. If Anne made 11 history errors, then Gail made one more geography error than Anne (10) and Susan made one less geography error than Louella (8). But again, since no one made 13 geography errors, clue 3 still doesn't work. So Anne made 12 history errors.
The twins with 11 errors made one more geography error than Susan (8) and one less than Gail (10), so Gail made 12 or 16 geography errors and Susan made 10 or 14 : while twins with 11 history errors made 11 or 15 geography errors. Thus those with 11 history errors made 15 geography errors (4), Gail made 16 geography errors and Susan made 14. Edward made 12 history errors (6) so is Anne's brother; Anne and her brother made either 10, 11 or 12 geography errors, so (6) made 11 or 12 and Luke and his sister made 10 or 11, ie one of them made 11. Luke's sister isn't Louella (1), so Luke made either six or eight history errors, as did David (5). Thus David's sister is Gail.
Anne made 11 geography errors (3), so Luke made 10 and Louella made 12. Sammy's sister is Susan (1). Wendy made 10 geography errors (12), so Diane made 15. Luke (who is Wendy's brother) made six history errors (12), so David made eight. By elimination, Sammy made seven and so is Susan's brother. Martin's sister is Louella (11). Diane's brother is George. Edwards is surnamed O'Connell (2) and the Dean girl is either Louella or Wendy (10 or 12 geography errors). The Waters and Seal twins (9) made either eight and seven history errors or else 11 and 10; so the Seal twins made 14 or 12 geography errors and the McCall twins made 10 or 12. If the Seal twins made 12 geography errors and the McCall twins made 10, then (above) the Dean twins are excluded. Thus Sammy's surname is Seal and David's is Waters. Diane's surname is Vole. Martin's isn't McCall (7), so must be Dean. Luke's is McCall.
Thus ( geography-history );
David - Gail - Waters - 16 -8;
Edward - Anne - O'Connell - 11- 12;
George - Diane - Vole - 15 - 11;
Luke - Wendy - McCall - 10 - 6;
Martin - Louella - Dean - 12 - 10;
Sammy - Susan - Seal - 14 - 7;
Hint: Susan made seven history errors (clue 8) and no one made nine, so Anne made either 11 or 12.

Question:
Question: In a forest somewhere in Scotland lives a group of 100 dwarves. Each night they meet in the middle of the forest for a grand feast.  When morning comes, they all go home.  Each dwarf is wearing either a red hat or a blue hat. Curiously, there are no mirrors in the forest, so no dwarf knows the color of his own hat. A dwarf would never take off his hat to see its color, and a major dwarf faux pas is to comment on the color of another dwarf's hat.  The dwarves know, however, that there is at least one red hatted dwarf and one blue hatted dwarf. One day, the master dwarf announces that the nightly feast will only be intended for blue hatted dwarves, and as soon as a dwarf knows that he is wearing a red hat, he should not come back the next day, and he should never return.
How many days does it take before there are no dwarves left with red hats at the party? (Assume all the dwarves are equally capable of figuring it out, in other words, there are no smart dwarves, and no stupid dwarves...)
 Solution: It will take one more day than the number of dwarves with red hats.
How this works is: assume that there is only one red-hatted dwarf. He would go to the party only to see 99 blue hats. He knows that there is at least one red hat. Since all he sees is blue, he knows it must be him, so he knows not to come back the next day. Meanwhile, the blue hatted dwarves can only see one red hat, so they think that if he comes back tomorrow, then he must have seen another red hat.  Since each blue hatted dwarf only sees one red hat, he would assume that if the red hatted dwarf came back tomorrow, then he must be the other red hat that the first red hatted dwarf saw. So the second day, all the blue hatted dwarves would come expecting to see if the red hatted dwarf came back. Which he wouldn't, because he knows he has a red hat. So the first day there are no dwarves with red hats is day 2, or one day more than the number of dwarves with red hats.
If there were two dwarves with red hats, each red hatted dwarf would realize on the second day that he was wearing a red hat, because he would see that the other red hat had come back, and that means that he must have seen another red hat. Since the red hats would see 98 blue hats, they would know on the second day, and the third day would be the first day that no red hatted dwarves came to the feast. This same system works for any number of red hats, because each time a blue hatted dwarf is thinking that if the red hats come back tomorrow, then he must have a red hat, the red hatted dwarves already know, and so they don't come the next day.
Hint: The number of days depends on the number of red hats.
Human Solution:
It will take one more day than the number of dwarves with red hats.
How this works is: assume that there is only one red-hatted dwarf. He would go to the party only to see 99 blue hats. He knows that there is at least one red hat. Since all he sees is blue, he knows it must be him, so he knows not to come back the next day. Meanwhile, the blue hatted dwarves can only see one red hat, so they think that if he comes back tomorrow, then he must have seen another red hat.  Since each blue hatted dwarf only sees one red hat, he would assume that if the red hatted dwarf came back tomorrow, then he must be the other red hat that the first red hatted dwarf saw. So the second day, all the blue hatted dwarves would come expecting to see if the red hatted dwarf came back. Which he wouldn't, because he knows he has a red hat. So the first day there are no dwarves with red hats is day 2, or one day more than the number of dwarves with red hats.
If there were two dwarves with red hats, each red hatted dwarf would realize on the second day that he was wearing a red hat, because he would see that the other red hat had come back, and that means that he must have seen another red hat. Since the red hats would see 98 blue hats, they would know on the second day, and the third day would be the first day that no red hatted dwarves came to the feast. This same system works for any number of red hats, because each time a blue hatted dwarf is thinking that if the red hats come back tomorrow, then he must have a red hat, the red hatted dwarves already know, and so they don't come the next day.
Response:
Here is a summary of the solution based on the provided text:

**SUMMARY:**

1.  **State the Conclusion:** The number of days it takes before no red-hatted dwarves come to the feast is one more day than the actual number of red-hatted dwarves present initially.
2.  **Establish Shared Knowledge:** All dwarves are logical, hear the master dwarf's announcement (that only blue-hatted dwarves should feast and red-hatted dwarves must leave when they know their hat color), see everyone else's hat color, and know there is at least one red and one blue hat.
3.  **Explain the Base Case (1 Red Hat):** If there is only one red-hatted dwarf, he sees only blue hats. Since he knows there is at least one red hat and he sees none on others, he logically deduces that he must be the one red-hatted dwarf. He makes this deduction on the first day and therefore does not attend the feast on the second day.
4.  **Explain the Next Case (2 Red Hats):** If there are two red-hatted dwarves, each sees one other red hat on day 1. Neither can immediately know their own color. However, each red-hatted dwarf expects that if they themselves were blue, the *single* red-hatted dwarf they see would have figured it out on day 1 (based on the logic from step 3) and would not show up on day 2. When both red-hatted dwarves *do* show up on day 2, each realizes the *other* red-hatted dwarf must have seen *more than one* red hat (including oneself) to not have left. This observation on day 2 allows each red-hatted dwarf to deduce that *they themselves* must be the second red hat. They make this deduction on day 2 and therefore do not attend the feast on day 3.
5.  **Generalize the Pattern:** This pattern continues. If there are 'R' red-hatted dwarves, each red-hatted dwarf sees R-1 red hats. On any given day 'N', a red-hatted dwarf thinks: "If there were only N-1 red hats in total among those I see (meaning I must be blue), then those N-1 red-hatted dwarves would have figured it out by day N (based on the logic for N-1 hats) and would not have shown up today." Since the other R-1 red-hatted dwarves *do* show up until day R+1, the red-hatted dwarves use this lack of departure on day R as proof that the total number of red hats among them is R, including themselves. They make this final deduction on day R.
6.  **Determine the Day of Absence:** Since the red-hatted dwarves make their definitive deduction on day R (where R is the total number of red hats), they know not to return for the feast starting on day R+1. Therefore, day R+1 is the first day when no red-hatted dwarves are present at the feast.

With Kelsey, Anna, and Abby in the back (10th, 11th, and 12th places), that means Luke, Brad, and Clark were in 7th, 8th, and 9th. Luke and Brad switched places as well, which put Luke in 8th, and Brad in 9th. The 11th and 12th place people switched places too, which put Kelsey in 11th, and Abby in 12th.
On the third lap the 10th and 11th place people switched spots, putting Kelsey in 10th, and Felicia in 11th. 5th and 6th place switched, making Brianna in 5th, and Clark in 6th, and the 7th and 8th place people switched, putting Luke in 7th and Anna in 8th. Question:
Question: In Numberrangements, you are given an arrangement of letters. The letters represent all of the whole numbers from 1 to the total number of letters used. Each letter represents a different number. Using the clues given, find which number each letter represents.
ABC
DEF
GHI
1. The sum of the top row is greater than the sum of the middle row, which is greater than the sum of the bottom row.
2. E is a prime factor of G.
3. F is greater than A.
4. The sum of B and G is equal to H.
5. I is not 1.
 Solution: A=7, B=1, C=9
D=6, E=2, F=8
G=4, H=5, I=3
From Clue 2, E must be 2, 3, 5, or 7, but it cannot be 5 or 7 because that would force G to be a greater multiple of 5 or 7, and only the numbers 1 to 9 are used. E must be 2 or 3 and G must be 4, 6, 8, or 9.
Let's try I=2. In that case, E=3 and G=6. H must be greater than 6 because of Clue 4. The most G+H+I can be is 14 because of Clue 1, since the sum of all nine numbers is only 45. So, I cannot be 2, and it therefore must be at least 3 because of Clue 5.
If I=4, then G cannot be 4, and must be 6, 8, or 9. Again, since H must be greater than G, the bottom row's sum will be too high.  If I = 5, then the minimums for G and H would be 4 and 6, respectively -- a sum of 15. If I = 6, then the minimum sum again is 15.
This means I MUST be 3, which forces E=2 and G=4, 6, or 8.  If G is 6 or 8, the sum of the bottom row will be too great, so G=4. The greatest that H can be is 7, which also means that B can only be 1, 2, or 3, from Clue 4. But 2 and 3 are already used, so B=1 and H=5.
This leaves A, C, D, and F, to be paired with 6, 7, 8, and 9, in some order. We know from Clue 1 that A+B+C > D+E+F, but E is already 1 greater than B, and from Clue 3, we know that F > A. This means that C must be at least 3 greater than D to make up for the top row trailing by at least 2. So, C must be 9, and D must be 6. This leaves 7 and 8 to be A and F, so of course, F=8 and A=7.
Hint: Start with casework on clue 2.
Human Solution:
A=7, B=1, C=9
D=6, E=2, F=8
G=4, H=5, I=3
From Clue 2, E must be 2, 3, 5, or 7, but it cannot be 5 or 7 because that would force G to be a greater multiple of 5 or 7, and only the numbers 1 to 9 are used. E must be 2 or 3 and G must be 4, 6, 8, or 9.
Let's try I=2. In that case, E=3 and G=6. H must be greater than 6 because of Clue 4. The most G+H+I can be is 14 because of Clue 1, since the sum of all nine numbers is only 45. So, I cannot be 2, and it therefore must be at least 3 because of Clue 5.
If I=4, then G cannot be 4, and must be 6, 8, or 9. Again, since H must be greater than G, the bottom row's sum will be too high.  If I = 5, then the minimums for G and H would be 4 and 6, respectively -- a sum of 15. If I = 6, then the minimum sum again is 15.
This means I MUST be 3, which forces E=2 and G=4, 6, or 8.  If G is 6 or 8, the sum of the bottom row will be too great, so G=4. The greatest that H can be is 7, which also means that B can only be 1, 2, or 3, from Clue 4. But 2 and 3 are already used, so B=1 and H=5.
This leaves A, C, D, and F, to be paired with 6, 7, 8, and 9, in some order. We know from Clue 1 that A+B+C > D+E+F, but E is already 1 greater than B, and from Clue 3, we know that F > A. This means that C must be at least 3 greater than D to make up for the top row trailing by at least 2. So, C must be 9, and D must be 6. This leaves 7 and 8 to be A and F, so of course, F=8 and A=7.
Response:
Okay, here is a summary of the solution to the Numberrangements puzzle, broken down into logical steps:

1.  **Understand the Rules:** The letters A through I represent the numbers 1 through 9, with each letter representing a different number. There are also several clues that must be satisfied.
2.  **Analyze Clue 2 (E & G Relationship):** Clue 2 states that E is a prime factor of G. Given that E and G must be numbers from 1 to 9, E must be one of the prime numbers 2, 3, 5, or 7. E cannot be 5 or 7 because the only multiples of 5 or 7 in the range 1-9 (excluding E itself) are 5 and 7, respectively, and E must be a *factor* of G, meaning G must be a *multiple* of E and G must be different from E. Thus, E must be either 2 or 3. This limits the possible pairs for (E, G) to (2,4), (2,6), (2,8), (3,6), or (3,9).
3.  **Analyze Clue 1 (Row Sum Ordering) and Total Sum:** Clue 1 states the sum of the top row (A+B+C) is greater than the sum of the middle row (D+E+F), which is greater than the sum of the bottom row (G+H+I). The total sum of all numbers from 1 to 9 is 45. For the sums to be strictly decreasing integers, the smallest possible sum for the bottom row (G+H+I) must be 14 or less (because if the bottom sum were 15, the middle must be at least 16, and the top at least 17, summing to at least 15+16+17=48, which is more than the total sum of 45). So, G+H+I ≤ 14.
4.  **Analyze Clue 5 (I ≠ 1) and Test Possible Values for I:** Clue 5 states that I is not 1. Test the smallest possible integer value for I, which is 2.
5.  **Test I=2:** If I=2, E cannot be 2 (as numbers are unique). From step 2, E must be 3. If E=3, G must be a multiple of 3 from {1-9} excluding 2 and 3, so G can be 6 or 9.
    *   If G=6, Clue 4 (B+G=H) means B+6=H, so H must be greater than 6. Possible H values from remaining numbers (1,4,5,7,8,9) are 7 (if B=1), 8 (if B=2, but E=2), or 9 (if B=3, but I=3). The only valid option is B=1, H=7. In this case, G+H+I = 6+7+2 = 15. This violates the condition from step 3 (G+H+I ≤ 14), so G cannot be 6 if I=2.
    *   If G=9, Clue 4 means B+9=H, so H must be greater than 9. No number from 1 to 9 is greater than 9, so G cannot be 9.
    *   Since neither possibility for G works when I=2, I cannot be 2.
6.  **Rule Out Other Values for I (4, 5, 6):** Consider other possible values for I (which cannot be 1 or 2, and is unlikely to be 7, 8, or 9 as that would make G+H+I very large). The solution rules out I=4, 5, and 6 by noting that in each case, even using the smallest possible remaining numbers for G and H (while satisfying the other clues like E being a prime factor of G and H > G), the sum G+H+I would exceed 14. This confirms that I must be less than 7. Given I ≠ 1, 2, 4, 5, 6, I must be 3.
7.  **Determine E, G, B, and H based on I=3:** If I=3, E must be 2 (from step 2, as E ≠ 3). Possible G values (mult of 2 from {1-9} excluding 2 and 3) are 4, 6, or 8. Use Clue 4 (B+G=H, H>G) and G+H+I ≤ 14 (G+H+3 ≤ 14 => G+H ≤ 11).
    *   If G=6, H=B+6 > 6. H from remaining numbers. G+H = 6+H ≤ 11 => H ≤ 5. There is no number > 6 and ≤ 5. G cannot be 6.
    *   If G=8, H=B+8 > 8. H must be 9 (if B=1). G+H = 8+9 = 17 > 11. G cannot be 8.
    *   If G=4, H=B+4 > 4. H from remaining numbers {1,5,6,7,8,9}. H ≥ 5. G+H = 4+H ≤ 11 => H ≤ 7. Possible H values are 5, 6, 7.
        *   If H=6, B=2 (but E=2, used).
        *   If H=7, B=3 (but I=3, used).
        *   If H=5, B=1 (1 is available). This is the only possibility.
8.  **Confirm Initial Assignments:** Based on the above logic, I=3, E=2, G=4, B=1, and H=5 are uniquely determined. The numbers used are {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}. The remaining numbers for A, C, D, and F are {6, 7, 8, 9}.
9.  **Determine A, C, D, and F:** The remaining letters A, C, D, F must represent the numbers {6, 7, 8, 9}. Use Clue 3 (F > A) and the simplified version of Clue 1 (A+C > D+F+1, derived from A+1+C > D+2+F).
10. **Test Combinations for A, C, D, F:** Consider pairs for (A, F) from {6,7,8,9} such that F > A. Assign the remaining two numbers to C and D, and check if A+C > D+F+1 holds. The only combination from {6,7,8,9} that satisfies F>A and allows A+C > D+F+1 with the remaining numbers for C and D is A=7 and F=8. When A=7 and F=8, the remaining numbers for C and D are 6 and 9. To satisfy A+C > D+F+1 (7+C > D+8+1 => 7+C > D+9 => C > D+2), C must be 9 and D must be 6 (9 > 6+2 = 8).
11. **State Final Assignments:** The determined values are A=7, B=1, C=9, D=6, E=2, F=8, G=4, H=5, I=3. These assignments use each number from 1 to 9 exactly once and satisfy all the given clues.

Question:
Question: In the following code, each symbol stands for one of five letters.
! stands for T, E, O, Z, or Y
? stands for F, G, A, Q, or I
# stands for N, I, W, A, or U
$ stands for T, E, N, I, or H
< stands for R, C, A, S, or B
* stands for I, D, E, U, or S
& stands for J, I, E, P, or K
^ stands for O, L, G, I, or H
> stands for L, S, N, C, or E
The nine letter code word, <$^&?*!#>, can be translated into two English words that are opposites. What are the two words?
 Solution: Religious and Atheistic.
Hint: Belief
Human Solution: Religious and Atheistic.
Response:
Okay, here is a summary of the solution to the problem, broken down into simple steps:

1.  **Understand the Code Structure:** The problem states that a nine-symbol code `<$^&?*!#>` translates into a nine-letter English word. This nine-letter word is one of a pair of opposite English words. Each symbol in the code corresponds to one possible letter from a given list of five letters.

2.  **Examine Symbol-Letter Mappings:** Look at the list of possible letters for each of the nine symbols in the code `<$^&?*!#>`. For example, the first symbol `<` can be R, C, A, S, or B.

3.  **Identify Candidate Words:** The solution provided gives the two opposite words: "Religious" and "Atheistic". One of these 9-letter words must be formed by the 9-symbol code.

4.  **Verify Word Formation (Word 1):** Check if the letters of the word "Religious" can be formed by selecting one allowed letter for each symbol in the correct order.
    *   < can be R (Yes)
    *   $ can be E (Yes)
    *   ^ can be L (Yes)
    *   & can be I (Yes)
    *   ? can be G (Yes)
    *   * can be I (Yes)
    *   ! can be O (Yes)
    *   # can be U (Yes)
    *   > can be S (Yes)
    Since "Religious" can be formed, it is a valid candidate word from the code.

5.  **Verify Word Formation (Word 2):** Check if the letters of the word "Atheistic" can also be formed by selecting one allowed letter for each symbol in the correct order.
    *   < can be A (Yes)
    *   $ can be T (Yes)
    *   ^ can be H (Yes)
    *   & can be E (Yes)
    *   ? can be I (Yes)
    *   * can be S (Yes)
    *   ! can be T (Yes)
    *   # can be I (Yes)
    *   > can be C (Yes)
    Since "Atheistic" can also be formed, it is also a valid candidate word from the code.

6.  **Confirm Opposite Relationship:** Check if "Religious" and "Atheistic" are a pair of opposite English words (Yes, they are).

7.  **Conclude the Solution:** Since both "Religious" and "Atheistic" can be formed by the code's possible letters and are a pair of opposites, they are the two words the problem asks for. The code translates into one of these words, and the solution lists both as the answer.

Question: MADADIA has been chosen to host the latest United Nations Kebab Annual Liaisons (U.N.K.A.L).
Madadia's mayoress, Madka Owdiseez, has invited several wives of delegates of UNKAL for an informal luncheon.
She plans to seat her 9 guests in a row such that each lady will be able to converse with the person directly to her left and right. She has prepared the following list.
Mrs. F speaks English only.
Mrs. G speaks English and French.
Mrs. H speaks English and Russian.
Mrs. J speaks Russian only.
Mrs. K speaks English only.
Mrs. L speaks French only.
Mrs. M speaks French and German.
Mrs. N speaks English and German.
Mrs. O speaks English only.
How many distinct seating arrangements are possible? Give all possible seating arrangements. Bear in mind that Madka Owdiseez is not one of the 9 to be seated in a row.
Note that ABCD and DCBA are the same
 Solution: With each arrangement considered identical to its reverse, there are 126 possible arrangements.
FKO are interchangeable, and can be arranged 6 ways. FKO stays together unless N is next to M outside GLM (more on that below).
JH must be together, and J must be at the end, because H is the only other Russian speaker. JH has 2 slots in the above configuration (H next to FKO, with J on the outside).
GLM has 1 slot in the above configuration (G next to FKO, opposite JH).
2[JH]*6[FKO]*1[MLG]=12 arrangements, or 2 mirror groups of 6 arrangements each. Thus, 6 distinct arrangements - 1 for each FKO order.
Keeping the above groups self-contained, N has 5 slots (2 within FKO, 1 between FKO and H, 1 between FKO and G, 1 beside M). That makes 30 arrangements - 5 for each FKO order.
When N is in certain positions, however, the groups can break up. Unless N is next to M outside GLM, GLM can be GML. If N is between FKO and GLM, GLM can scramble, and G can be anywhere touching FKO, except N cannot touch L. When G-[L/M]-N are consecutive in either direction, FKO can straddle that subgroup. That makes 126 arrangements - 21 for each FKO order.
Here are the 21 arrangements, using xxx for the interchangeable FKO.
JHNxxxGLM, JHNxxxGML, JHxNxxGLM, JHxNxxGML
JHxxNxGLM, JHxxNxGML, JHxxxNGLM, JHxxxNGML
JHxxxNMGL, JHxxxNMLG, JHxxNMLGx, JHxNMLGxx
JHNMLGxxx, JHxxxGLMN, JHxxGLMNx, JHxGLMNxx
JHGLMNxxx, JHGxxxNML, JHxGxxNML, JHxxGxNML
JHxxxGNML
Apply each FKO order - F-K-O, F-O-K, K-F-O, K-O-F, O-F-K, O-K-F - to each xxx above. That makes 21*6=126 arrangements.
Hint: FKO are interchangeable, and can be arranged 6 ways. FKO stays together unless N is next to M outside GLM (more on that below).
Human Solution:
With each arrangement considered identical to its reverse, there are 126 possible arrangements.
FKO are interchangeable, and can be arranged 6 ways. FKO stays together unless N is next to M outside GLM (more on that below).
JH must be together, and J must be at the end, because H is the only other Russian speaker. JH has 2 slots in the above configuration (H next to FKO, with J on the outside).
GLM has 1 slot in the above configuration (G next to FKO, opposite JH).
2[JH]*6[FKO]*1[MLG]=12 arrangements, or 2 mirror groups of 6 arrangements each. Thus, 6 distinct arrangements - 1 for each FKO order.
Keeping the above groups self-contained, N has 5 slots (2 within FKO, 1 between FKO and H, 1 between FKO and G, 1 beside M). That makes 30 arrangements - 5 for each FKO order.
When N is in certain positions, however, the groups can break up. Unless N is next to M outside GLM, GLM can be GML. If N is between FKO and GLM, GLM can scramble, and G can be anywhere touching FKO, except N cannot touch L. When G-[L/M]-N are consecutive in either direction, FKO can straddle that subgroup. That makes 126 arrangements - 21 for each FKO order.
Here are the 21 arrangements, using xxx for the interchangeable FKO.
JHNxxxGLM, JHNxxxGML, JHxNxxGLM, JHxNxxGML
JHxxNxGLM, JHxxNxGML, JHxxxNGLM, JHxxxNGML
JHxxxNMGL, JHxxxNMLG, JHxxNMLGx, JHxNMLGxx
JHNMLGxxx, JHxxxGLMN, JHxxGLMNx, JHxGLMNxx
JHGLMNxxx, JHGxxxNML, JHxGxxNML, JHxxGxNML
JHxxxGNML
Apply each FKO order - F-K-O, F-O-K, K-F-O, K-O-F, O-F-K, O-K-F - to each xxx above. That makes 21*6=126 arrangements.

Question:
Question: A man named Stewart is traveling all over the world. First he travels to Cape Town in South Africa. Then to Jakarta in Indonesia. Then to Canberra in Australia. Then to Rome in Italy. Then to Panama City in Panama. Where does he travel next?
 Solution: Santiago in Chile. He travels to each continent in alphabetical order then to the capital of the country that has the most southern latitude.
Hint: Each time he travels to a continent he has not traveled to.
Human Solution: Santiago in Chile. He travels to each continent in alphabetical order then to the capital of the country that has the most southern latitude.
Response:
SUMMARY:
1.  Identify the first part of the pattern: Stewart travels to a major city/capital in a country located on continents in alphabetical order.
2.  Verify this part of the pattern with the given sequence: Africa (Cape Town), Asia (Jakarta), Australia/Oceania (Canberra), Europe (Rome), North America (Panama City). The next continent in alphabetical order is South America.
3.  Identify the second part of the pattern: Within that continent, he travels to the capital of the country with the most southern latitude.
4.  Determine the southernmost country on the next continent (South America), which is Chile.
5.  Identify the capital of Chile, which is Santiago.
6.  Conclude that based on the pattern, Stewart travels next to Santiago in Chile.

Question: The boffins from NASA have received and decoded a digital message from the Galactic Council, informing them that four alien ambassadors from the solar system are due to visit Earth in the next 24 hours. The aliens are Agurgle from Uranus, Wym-Inar from Venus, ChimChim from Pluto and Mr. Arthur Johnson from Saturn. 24 hours later, they receive a mystery message saying that if any alien comes off the ship that is green, tentacled and slimy, then they are actually an undercover assassin from Neptune. By then, however, the aliens have all landed and are in adjacent decontamination booths, waiting to be let in to NASA Headquarters. One alien turns out to be green, tentacled and slimy!
From the clues below, who is the Neptunian Assassin?
1) Wym-Inar from Venus is the only ambassador in a booth next to exactly one tentacled alien.
2). Two of the ambassadors who are not green, are each in booths next to Agurgle from Uranus.
3) ChimChim from Pluto is the only ambassador not in a booth next to exactly one Un-slimy alien.
Who do the NASA boffins not let out of the booth?
 Solution: ChimChim from Pluto is green, tentacled and slimy and so, is the Assassin.
Looking at clue 2 we know that both the ambassadors standing next to Agurgle from Uranus are not green. Also, from the body of the teaser, we also know only one alien is green, tentacled and slimy. So there are two deductions to be made: (Note the key is - Alien (Green, Tentacled, Un-Slimey). Where "Y" stands for Yes and "N" stands for No. "?" denotes unknown, and each set of braces[] indicates a booth)
Either Deduction A
[ N, ?, ?] [Agurgle from Uranus Y, Y, N] [ N, ?, ?] [ ?, ?, ?]
Or Deduction B
[N, ?, ?] [Agurgle from Uranus ?, ?, ?][ N, ?, ?] [Y, Y, N]
You can see that either Agurgle from Uranus or the alien at the extreme right hand booth is green, tentacled and slimy.
Now taking clue 3, you can work out that ChimChim from Pluto's booth is next to a slimy alien AND each of the other aliens' booths are next to precisely one slimy alien.
So, based on the first set of deductions, you can infer the following.
Deduction A (ii):
[ChimChim from Pluto N, ?, N] [Agurgle from Uranus Y, Y, N] [N, ?, Y] [?, ?, Y]
Or Deduction B (ii):
[N, ?, Y] [Agurgle from Uranus ?, ?, Y][ N, ?, N] [ChimChim from Pluto Y, Y, N]
You can then use clue 1 to eliminate one of these deductions: Wym-Inar from Venus is the only alien in a booth next to exactly one tentacled alien. But in Deduction A(ii), ChimChim from Pluto's booth is next to exactly one tentacled alien.  Therefore, Deduction A (ii) is not possible and Deduction B (ii) is the correct one.
Deduction B (ii):
[N, ?, Y] [Agurgle from Uranus ?, ?, Y][ N, ?, N] [ChimChim from Pluto Y, Y, N]
So, looking again at clues 2 and 3, there are a further 2 possible deductions to be made.
Deduction A (iii)
[Mr. Arthur Johnson from Saturn N, N, Y] [Agurgle from Uranus] [?, N, Y] [Wym-Inar from Venus N, N, N][ChimChim from Pluto Y, Y, N]
Deduction B (iii)
[Wym-Inar from Venus N, N, Y][Agurgle from Uranus ?, Y, Y][Mr. Arthur Johnson from Saturn N, N, N][ChimChim from Pluto Y, Y, N]
So, ChimChim from Pluto is green, tentacled and slimy, and is therefore our Neptunian Assassin.
Hint: Don't get too confused with the Un-slimy bit.
Human Solution:
ChimChim from Pluto is green, tentacled and slimy and so, is the Assassin.
Looking at clue 2 we know that both the ambassadors standing next to Agurgle from Uranus are not green. Also, from the body of the teaser, we also know only one alien is green, tentacled and slimy. So there are two deductions to be made: (Note the key is - Alien (Green, Tentacled, Un-Slimey). Where "Y" stands for Yes and "N" stands for No. "?" denotes unknown, and each set of braces[] indicates a booth)
Either Deduction A
[ N, ?, ?] [Agurgle from Uranus Y, Y, N] [ N, ?, ?] [ ?, ?, ?]
Or Deduction B
[N, ?, ?] [Agurgle from Uranus ?, ?, ?][ N, ?, ?] [Y, Y, N]
You can see that either Agurgle from Uranus or the alien at the extreme right hand booth is green, tentacled and slimy.
Now taking clue 3, you can work out that ChimChim from Pluto's booth is next to a slimy alien AND each of the other aliens' booths are next to precisely one slimy alien.
So, based on the first set of deductions, you can infer the following.
Deduction A (ii):
[ChimChim from Pluto N, ?, N] [Agurgle from Uranus Y, Y, N] [N, ?, Y] [?, ?, Y]
Or Deduction B (ii):
[N, ?, Y] [Agurgle from Uranus ?, ?, Y][ N, ?, N] [ChimChim from Pluto Y, Y, N]
You can then use clue 1 to eliminate one of these deductions: Wym-Inar from Venus is the only alien in a booth next to exactly one tentacled alien. But in Deduction A(ii), ChimChim from Pluto's booth is next to exactly one tentacled alien.  Therefore, Deduction A (ii) is not possible and Deduction B (ii) is the correct one.
Deduction B (ii):
[N, ?, Y] [Agurgle from Uranus ?, ?, Y][ N, ?, N] [ChimChim from Pluto Y, Y, N]
So, looking again at clues 2 and 3, there are a further 2 possible deductions to be made.
Deduction A (iii)
[Mr. Arthur Johnson from Saturn N, N, Y] [Agurgle from Uranus] [?, N, Y] [Wym-Inar from Venus N, N, N][ChimChim from Pluto Y, Y, N]
Deduction B (iii)
[Wym-Inar from Venus N, N, Y][Agurgle from Uranus ?, Y, Y][Mr. Arthur Johnson from Saturn N, N, N][ChimChim from Pluto Y, Y, N]
So, ChimChim from Pluto is green, tentacled and slimy, and is therefore our Neptunian Assassin.
Response:
Here is a summary of the provided solution, broken down into simple steps:

1.  **Identify the Assassin's Traits:** The solution establishes that the Neptunian Assassin is the alien who is green, tentacled, and slimy.
2.  **Use Clue 2 for Initial Arrangement Possibilities:** The solution uses Clue 2, stating that two non-green ambassadors are next to Agurgle. This leads to two initial possible arrangements or deductions (labeled Deduction A and Deduction B) for the aliens in the four booths, using a notation [Green?, Tentacled?, Slimy?] for characteristics. The solution notes that one of the aliens in these arrangements must be the green, tentacled, slimy assassin.
3.  **Use Clue 3 to Refine Possibilities:** The solution applies Clue 3, concerning ChimChim from Pluto being the only alien *not* next to exactly one un-slimy alien. This step refines the initial possibilities, leading to updated arrangements/deductions labeled A(ii) and B(ii), adding more information about the aliens' traits based on this clue. It assigns ChimChim specific traits [Y,Y,N] at this stage.
4.  **Use Clue 1 to Eliminate a Possibility:** The solution then uses Clue 1, stating that Wym-Inar from Venus is the only alien next to exactly one tentacled alien. It uses this clue to eliminate one of the refined possibilities (Deduction A(ii)), concluding that Deduction B(ii) is the correct general arrangement and set of partial characteristics.
5.  **Present Further Deductions (Assigning Identities):** The solution states that looking again at clues 2 and 3 leads to two *further* possible deductions (A(iii) and B(iii)). These deductions assign specific alien identities (Mr. Arthur Johnson, Wym-Inar, and ChimChim) to booths within the arrangement and provide a set of characteristics for each [N,N,Y], [?,Y,Y], [N,N,N], [Y,Y,N].
6.  **State the Final Conclusion:** Based on the characteristics assigned to ChimChim from Pluto in the steps (listed as [Y,Y,N]), the solution concludes that ChimChim is the alien who is green, tentacled, and slimy, and therefore is the Neptunian Assassin who should not be let out of the booth.

Question: Four men are in a line at the Madadian Police station, charged with unlicensed kebab breeding.
The men are Mad Ade, Buster Artery, Cliff Hedge and Donny Moe - and they are standing in a straight line.
One man is fair, handsome and unscarred.
Two men who are not fair, are each standing next to Mad Ade
Buster Artery is the only man standing next to exactly one handsome man.
Cliff Hedge is the only man not standing next to exactly one scarred man.
Who is fair, handsome and unscarred?
 Solution: Cliff Hedge is fair, handsome and unscarred.
From (2), both the men standing next to Mad Ade are not fair. Also, exactly one man is fair, handsome and unscarred. Hence, there are two cases:
Case 1 :: ? (N, ?, ?) : Mad Ade (Y, Y, N) : ? (N, ?, ?) : ? (?, ?, ?)
Case 2 :: ? (N, ?, ?) : Mad Ade (?, ?, ?) : ? (N, ?, ?) : ? (Y, Y, N)

From (3), Buster Artery is the only man standing next to exactly one handsome man. But in Case 1, Cliff Hedge is standing next to exactly one handsome man. Hence, Case 1 is not possible and Case 2 is the correct one.
Case 2 :: ? (N, ?, Y) : Mad Ade (?, ?, Y) : ? (N, ?, N) : Cliff Hedge (Y, Y, N)
Again from (3) and (4), there are 2 possibilities as shown below.
Case 2a :: Donny Moe (N, N, Y) : Mad Ade (?, N, Y) : Buster Artery (N, N, N) : Cliff Hedge (Y, Y, N)
Case 2b :: Buster Artery (N, N, Y) : Mad Ade (?, Y, Y) : Donny Moe (N, N, N) : Cliff Hedge (Y, Y, N)
Thus, Cliff Hedge is fair, handsome and unscarred. Also, Mad Ade may be either fair or not fair.

Question:
Question: Mad Ade's rich uncle "Uncle Rich" owned the famous Madadian Race horse breeding stables "The Gluepot".
It has a private race track that has five lanes.
Uncle Rich has 25 horses and wishes to know which are the three fastest.
What is the least number of races needed to be run to find the answer?
Note that it is only the ranking of the horses being found not the actual timings.
 Solution: Answer: 7 races
Race #1 to Race #5 - Divide the horses into 5 groups of 5. Race each group to rank the first 3 in each - that's 5 races.
Race #6 - Race the winner from each group. The winner in this race is the fastest horse.
Race #7 - Race the second and third horses from the race in which the fastest horse raced initially,
the first and second horses from the group of the second horse in Race #6, and the third horse in Race #6 (that's a total of 5 horses).
The first and second horses in Race #7 are the second and third horses of the entire stable.
Hint: Subgroups!
Human Solution:
Answer: 7 races
Race #1 to Race #5 - Divide the horses into 5 groups of 5. Race each group to rank the first 3 in each - that's 5 races.
Race #6 - Race the winner from each group. The winner in this race is the fastest horse.
Race #7 - Race the second and third horses from the race in which the fastest horse raced initially,
the first and second horses from the group of the second horse in Race #6, and the third horse in Race #6 (that's a total of 5 horses).
The first and second horses in Race #7 are the second and third horses of the entire stable.
Response:
Here is a summary of the solution to the problem, broken down into simple, logical steps:

1.  **Divide and Race Initial Groups:** Divide the 25 horses into 5 groups of 5. Race each of these 5 groups. This requires 5 races. The purpose of these races is to identify the top contenders from each group and eliminate horses that finish 4th or 5th in their heat, as they cannot be among the top 3 overall. After these 5 races, you know the finishing order within each group.
2.  **Race the Group Winners:** Take the winner from each of the 5 initial groups and race these 5 horses against each other. This requires 1 race (Race #6). The winner of this race is the fastest horse overall, because it beat the fastest horse from every other group. The results of this race also help identify potential candidates for the 2nd and 3rd fastest overall. Let's say the winners' race results are W1, W2, W3, W4, W5 (where W1 is the overall fastest).
3.  **Identify Candidates for 2nd and 3rd:** Based on the results of the first 6 races, determine which horses could potentially be the 2nd and 3rd fastest overall. These potential candidates are:
    *   The 2nd and 3rd place horses from the initial group that the overall fastest horse (W1) came from.
    *   The winner (W2) and the 2nd place horse from the initial group that the 2nd place horse in the winners' race (W2) came from.
    *   The winner (W3) from the initial group that the 3rd place horse in the winners' race (W3) came from.
    Horses from groups whose winners finished 4th or 5th in the winners' race cannot be in the top 3 overall. This selection process yields exactly 5 candidates.
4.  **Race the Final Candidates:** Race these 5 candidates against each other. This requires 1 race (Race #7). The horse that finishes first in this race is the 2nd fastest horse overall, and the horse that finishes second is the 3rd fastest horse overall.
5.  **Calculate Total Races:** Sum the number of races from each step: 5 (initial heats) + 1 (winners' race) + 1 (final candidates race) = 7 races.

Question: In a wood-cutting factory, five large sawing machines stand in a windowless room. Each machine has an on/off switch attached, there being no doubt as to which switch controls which machine. Outside the door to the room are five back-up on/off switches, one for each machine inside. The power for each machine must first pass through the back-up switch, and then the machine switch before reaching the saw. The problem is, the new manager cannot decide how these back-up switches match with the machines inside the room. One day, the manager's brother visits. The manager takes him inside the sawing room where all five machines are at work and explains the problem. The brother announces that he intends to leave the room and that when he returns he will be able to match correctly the five switches outside the room to the five machines inside. The brother works alone, cannot see the machines from outside the room and solves the problem purely by operating switches. How is it possible?
 Solution: 1) Turn off two machines while inside. Let's call those two machines turned off with inside switch 'inactive', and call remaining three machines 'active'.
2) Go outside.
3) Find out which two outside switches correspond to inactive machines, and which correspond to active machines. To do that, try all of following ten combinations, where 'x' represents turned-off outside switch, while 'O' represent turned on switch: xxx00,xx0x0,x0xx0,0xxx0,xx00x,x0x0x,0xx0x,x00xx,0x0xx,00xxx . Only one of these combinations is a 'silent' combination that eliminates all sound, by turning off all three active machines.
4) Label outside switches related to active machines (those marked with 'x' in the silent combination) with A, B, and C. Label outside switches related to inactive machines with D and E.
5) For inactive machines, turn D off and E on.
6) For active machines, turn A and B on, and turn C off.
7) Wait enough time for machine connected to C switch to cool off, and then turn B off, too.
8) Go inside.
9) The only machine that is still working inside is connected to outside switch A.
10) Check both machines that were active and are now turned off. The one that is warmer is connected to switch B (since it was on most recently), and the cooler one is connected to switch C (which was turned off first).
11) Turn inside switches on for both 'inactive' machines. The one that starts working is connected to outside switch E. The one that is still not working is connected to outside switch D.
Hint: Aside from sight, use other senses.
Human Solution:
1) Turn off two machines while inside. Let's call those two machines turned off with inside switch 'inactive', and call remaining three machines 'active'.
2) Go outside.
3) Find out which two outside switches correspond to inactive machines, and which correspond to active machines. To do that, try all of following ten combinations, where 'x' represents turned-off outside switch, while 'O' represent turned on switch: xxx00,xx0x0,x0xx0,0xxx0,xx00x,x0x0x,0xx0x,x00xx,0x0xx,00xxx . Only one of these combinations is a 'silent' combination that eliminates all sound, by turning off all three active machines.
4) Label outside switches related to active machines (those marked with 'x' in the silent combination) with A, B, and C. Label outside switches related to inactive machines with D and E.
5) For inactive machines, turn D off and E on.
6) For active machines, turn A and B on, and turn C off.
7) Wait enough time for machine connected to C switch to cool off, and then turn B off, too.
8) Go inside.
9) The only machine that is still working inside is connected to outside switch A.
10) Check both machines that were active and are now turned off. The one that is warmer is connected to switch B (since it was on most recently), and the cooler one is connected to switch C (which was turned off first).
11) Turn inside switches on for both 'inactive' machines. The one that starts working is connected to outside switch E. The one that is still not working is connected to outside switch D.
Response:
SUMMARY:
The solution describes a method for the brother to determine which of the five outside switches corresponds to each of the five inside machines. The core idea is to manipulate the inside switches to create distinct states for the machines, and then use the outside switches to interact with these states, using sound (running/not running) and temperature (warm/cold) as indicators.

Here is the reasoning in simple steps:

1.  **Create Two Groups of Machines (Inside):** The brother initially goes inside the room. While inside, he turns the inside switches of two specific machines OFF. This leaves three machines with their inside switches ON and two with their inside switches OFF. Since both inside and outside switches must be ON for a machine to run, the three machines with inside switches ON are potentially "active" (can be controlled by the outside switch), while the two with inside switches OFF are "inactive" (cannot be turned on by the outside switch alone).
2.  **Move Outside:** The brother leaves the room. From outside, he cannot see the machines but can operate the five outside switches and hear the machines (if they are running).
3.  **Identify Outside Switches by Group (Outside):** The brother knows there are three machines whose inside switches are ON and two whose inside switches are OFF. He can test combinations of the five outside switches. By turning off various sets of three outside switches, he will find one specific combination that results in total silence (all machines stop). This happens *only* when the three outside switches corresponding to the three machines with inside switches ON (the "active" machines) are all turned OFF. The two outside switches *not* included in this silent combination must therefore correspond to the two machines with inside switches OFF (the "inactive" machines). This step successfully groups the outside switches into "Active Outside Switches" (AOS) and "Inactive Outside Switches" (IOS).
4.  **Label the Outside Switches (Outside):** The brother labels the three AOS (corresponding to machines with inside switches ON) and the two IOS (corresponding to machines with inside switches OFF).
5.  **Set Up Conditions for Differentiation within Groups (Outside):** To distinguish the individual switches within each group, the brother uses the outside switches to create different states that can be detected when he goes back inside. He operates the outside switches as follows:
    *   For the two IOS (inactive machines): He turns one outside switch OFF and the other ON. Note that operating these switches does not start the machines because their inside switches are OFF. This sets up a state for later.
    *   For the three AOS (active machines): He turns two of these outside switches ON and leaves the third one OFF. This causes the two corresponding machines (whose inside switches are ON) to start running.
6.  **Use Time to Create Temperature Differences (Outside):** He waits for a period of time while the two selected machines run. Then, he turns off *one* of the two AOS switches that he had turned ON. This stops one machine, while the other continues to run. This creates different running times for the three active machines: one ran for the whole period, one ran for part of the period and then stopped, and one never ran. This will result in different temperatures.
7.  **Move Back Inside:** The brother re-enters the room. He can now see the machines, check their running state, and feel their temperature.
8.  **Differentiate Within the Active Group (Inside):** Based on their current state and temperature, he can identify which machine corresponds to which AOS:
    *   The machine that is currently running is connected to the AOS that was left ON.
    *   Of the two machines that are now off but whose inside switches were ON, the one that is warmer is connected to the AOS that was turned ON for part of the time and then turned OFF.
    *   The machine that is cooler (or cold) is connected to the AOS that was left OFF the entire time.
    This identifies the machines matched to all three AOS.
9.  **Differentiate Within the Inactive Group (Inside):** Two machines remain unidentified; these are the ones whose inside switches were initially turned OFF (the inactive machines). Their corresponding outside switches are the two IOS (one left OFF, one left ON in step 5). The brother now turns the inside switch ON for one of these two remaining machines.
    *   If the machine starts running, its corresponding outside switch must be the IOS that was left ON in step 5.
    *   The last remaining machine must then be connected to the IOS that was left OFF in step 5 (it will not start running when its inside switch is turned ON until its corresponding outside switch is also turned ON).
10. **Completion:** By following these steps, the brother successfully matches all five outside switches to their corresponding five inside machines.

Response:
Here is a summary of the solution, broken down into simple, logical steps:

2.  **Use Relative Positions to Fix Key Suspects:** Combine clues involving specific suspects to deduce their exact positions.
    *   Clue 7: Six suspects stand *between* Chris Mass and Ewan Watarmy. This means there are 7 positions difference between them (e.g., positions `c` and `e` have `|c - e| = 7`).
    *   Clue 1: Chris Mass stood to the *right* of the main culprit (position 6). So Chris's position must be greater than 6.
    *   The only positions with a difference of 7 within the 1-11 range, where one position (Chris) is greater than 6, is if Ewan is at position 4 and Chris is at position 11 (|4 - 11| = 7, and 11 > 6).
    *   Now that Ewan is fixed at position 4, use Clues 2 and 8. Two suspects stood between Ewan and Lou Stooth (|4 - L| = 3), and two suspects stood between Ewan and Diddy Dewit (|4 - D| = 3). This means Lou and Diddy must be at positions 1 and 7 (4-3=1, 4+3=7), one at each position.
    *   Use Clue 5: Robin Banks and Polly Ester-Phants stood either side of Ewan Watarmy (at position 4). This means Robin and Polly must be at positions 3 and 5, one at each position.

3.  **Fix Remaining Large-Gap Positions:** Use Clue 3: Seven suspects stood between Mike Rhosopht and Phil Mypokits. This means there are 8 positions difference between them (|M - Ph| = 8). The only remaining positions with a difference of 8 are 2 and 10. Therefore, Mike and Phil must be at positions 2 and 10, one at each position.

4.  **Identify Remaining Suspects and Positions:** Positions 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 7, 10, and 11 are now assigned to suspects. The remaining positions are 6, 8, and 9. The remaining suspects are Hugo Phurst, Barb Dwyre, and Gerry Atrick. The main culprit is at position 6, so the culprit must be one of these three remaining suspects.

5.  **Use Final Clues to Identify the Culprit:** Apply the clues specific to the remaining suspects (Hugo, Barb, Gerry) to determine who is at position 6.
    *   Clue 1: Barb Dwyre stood to the right of the main culprit (position 6). This means Barb is at a position greater than 6. So Barb cannot be at position 6; she must be at position 8 or 9.
    *   This leaves either Hugo Phurst or Gerry Atrick at position 6.
    *   Clue 4: Gerry Atrick stood to the right of Hugo Phurst. This means Gerry's position is greater than Hugo's position.
    *   Consider the possibility that Gerry is the culprit (at position 6). If Gerry is at 6, then Hugo must be at a position less than 6 according to Clue 4. However, the only remaining positions for Hugo, Barb, and Gerry are 6, 8, and 9. Since Barb must be at 8 or 9, the only position left for Hugo if Gerry is at 6 would be either 8 or 9. But 8 and 9 are *not* less than 6, which contradicts Clue 4 (Gerry right of Hugo). Therefore, Gerry cannot be at position 6.
    *   The only remaining possibility for position 6 is Hugo Phurst. This fits all the clues: Hugo is at 6, Barb is at 8 or 9 (right of 6), and Gerry is at 8 or 9. If Hugo is at 6, and Gerry is at 8 or 9, then Gerry is to the right of Hugo (position > 6), satisfying Clue 4.

Therefore, the main culprit is Hugo Phurst.

Question: One of the most famous logic puzzles is the "Eight Queens puzzle".  The object of this puzzle is to place 8 chess queens on a standard 8x8 chessboard so that no queen can be captured by any of the other queens.
Logically, no queen can share the same row, column, or diagonal with any other queen.
Can you discover an arrangement that works?
 Solution: There are actually 12 completely unique solutions to this puzzle (unique meaning not simply rotating or flipping the board).
Using a standard system of numbering rows 1-8 moving away from the player and noting columns with letters a-h, here are the solutions:
1) a1, g2, e3, h4, b5, d6, f7, c8
2) a1, g2, d3, f4, h5, b6, e7, c8
3) c1, a2, g3, e4, h5, b6, d7, f8

7) e1, a2, h3, f4, c5, g6, b7, d8

9) e1, g2, a3, d4, b5, h6, f7, c8
10) f1, a2, e3, b4, h5, c6, g7, d8
11) f1, c2, a3, h4, d5, b6, g7, e8
12) g1, a2, c3, h4, f5, d6, b7, e8

Response:
SUMMARY:
1.  The problem asks to place 8 chess queens on an 8x8 board such that no two queens threaten each other.
2.  This means no two queens can be in the same row, the same column, or on the same diagonal.
3.  The provided solution states that there are 12 unique arrangements that satisfy these conditions.
4.  The solution then lists these 12 arrangements by specifying the position of each of the 8 queens on the board using standard chess notation (column-row, e.g., a1).
5.  Each listed set of 8 positions represents a valid configuration where no two queens attack each other, thus solving the puzzle.
